title: Three Arizona cities rank among nation's top meeting spots
text: Jim Poulin/Phoenix Business Journal #6: Phoenix Phoenix and Scottsdale are the only two Valley cities among the Top 50 U.S. meeting destinations, compiled by cloud-based event management platform Cvent . Phoenix jumped one spot higher this year from No. 11, making its way in the top ten, at No. 10, while Scottsdale slid down two positions this year from No. 16 to No. 18. Chandler sat at the bottom of the list last year at No. 50, but unfortunately did not make the top 50 this year. Folks in southern Arizona will be pleased to hear that Tucson made its way onto the list for the first time since 2013 at No. 48. Chicago lost its former glory at the top of the list and slid down to No. 3 this year, being overcome by Orlando at No. 1 and Las Vegas at No. 2. “Competition for meetings and conventions business continues to be very heated between destinations that are eager to attract events to boost their local economies,” said Bharet Malhotra , senior vice president of sales for the Cvent Supplier Network. “This year we witnessed several cities vying for a position in the top 50 list, with significant movement within the ranks. One of the interesting trends this year has been the rise of smaller cities moving ahead of and even displacing destinations that are near large metro areas but not downtown.” Tucson certainly was one of the smaller cities that enjoyed a boost in the rankings while Phoenix may be the exception to the rule, but it did host the Super Bowl at the beginning of this year.
